case_name: Workmen of Subong Tea Estate v. Management of Subong Tea Estate

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 132 of 1963 filed by special leave from the award dated July 5, 1961 of the Industrial Tribunal Assam on Reference No. 39/59.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 132 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the award date July 5, 1961 of the Industrial Tribunal Assam Reference No. 39 59.

facts.text: Industrial dispute arose between appellants (workmen of Subong Tea Estate) and management represented by respondents 1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: The industrial dispute which has given rise to this appeal arose between the appellants, the workmen of Subong Tea Estate, and the management of Subong Tea Estate represented by respondents 1 2.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1, Ms. Macneill Barry Ltd., managed Subong Tea Estate and transferred it to Respondent No. 2, Ms. Gungaram Tarachand otherwise known as Hindusthan Tea Company.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1, M s. Macneill Barry Ltd., who managed the Subong Tea Estate, has transferred the said estate to respondent No. 2, M s. Gungaram Tarachand otherwise known as Hindusthan Tea Company.

facts.text: On retrenchment of 8 employees, Respondent No. 1 paid adequate retrenchment compensation to them.

anchor.surface_text: On the occasion of the retrenchment of the 8 employees in question, respondent No. 1 has paid adequate retrenchment companypensation to them.

facts.text: Appellants contended that at the relevant date of retrenchment of 8 workmen, Respondent No. 2 was their employer, so Respondent No. 1 had no authority.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, however, companytended that at the relevant date when the 8 workmen were retrenched, respondent No. 2 was their employer, and so, respondent No. 1 had numberauthority to pass the orders of retrenchment.

facts.text: Impugned retrenchment invalid as not justified under s. 25F and not carried out per s. 25G of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: It was further their case that the impugned retrenchment is invalid and illegal inasmuch as it is number justified under s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  No. 14 of 1947   hereinafter called the Act , and has number been carried out according to the principles prescribed by s. 25G of the said Act.

facts.text: Dispute referred by Governor of Assam to Industrial Tribunal Assam under s. 10(1)(d) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: That is how the dispute in regard to the impugned retrenchment came to be referred by the Governor of Assam for industrial adjudication to the Industrial Tribunal, Assam, under s. 10 1   d  of the Act.

facts.text: Four issues referred to Tribunal: (1) whether retrenchment justified; (2) whether Resp2 justified in refusing continuity; (3) entitlement to reinstatement; (4) further relief if valid.

anchor.surface_text: Four issues were referred to the Tribunal for its adjudication. The first issue was whether the impugned retrenchment of the 8 workmen was justified the second was whether respondent No. 2, the transferee Co., was justified in refusing to maintain the companytinuity of service and original terms and companyditions of the workmen companycerned under the third issue, the Tribunal was required to companysider whether the workmen companycerned were entitled to reinstatement and any other relief the fourth issue which was added some time later, required the Tribunal to decide whether the retrenched workmen were entitled to any further relief in case their retrenchment was held to be valid.

facts.text: Tribunal answered all issues against appellants except recommended gratuity ex gratia for two employees (G.C. Bhattacharjee and P.K. Sarma Chowdhury).

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has answered all these questions against the appellants, except in regard to two employees Mr. G. C. Bhattacharjee and Mr. P. K. Sarma Chowdhury in whose cases the Tribunal has recommended that respondent No. 1 should pay them gratuity ex gratia in such sums as respondent No. 1 may companysider reasonable with due regard to companypensation already paid to them.

facts.text: Agreement of transfer between Resp1 (Vendor) and Resp2 (Vendee) reached on 12th January 1959, to take effect from 1st January 1959, subject to RBI approval.

anchor.surface_text: Before dealing with the points of law raised in the present appeal by Mr. Sen Gupta on behalf of the appellants, it is necessary to state the material facts in some detail. The agreement of transfer between respondent No. 1 and respondent No. 2  hereafter called the Vendor and the Vendee respectively  was reached on the 12th January, 1959.

facts.text: RBI approval accorded on 15th July 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The said approval was accorded on the 15th July, 1959, and the companyveyance was actually executed on the 28th December, 1959.

facts.text: Conveyance executed on 28th December 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The said approval was accorded on the 15th July, 1959, and the companyveyance was actually executed on the 28th December, 1959.

facts.text: Vendee put in possession of tea garden on 17th February 1959 pending execution of conveyance.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the execution of the companyveyance, on the 17th February, 1959, the Vendee was put in possession of the tea garden. These facts are number in dispute.

facts.text: Notices served on 8 employees by Mr. Hammond (Manager of Vendor) on 31st August 1959, services terminated effective 1st October 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On the 31st August, 1959, Mr. Hammond, the Manager of the Vender Co., served numberices on the 8 employees in question intimating to them that their services would be terminated with effect from the 1st October, 1959.

facts.text: Retrenchment compensation under s.25F and pro rata leave wages paid to 8 employees on 31st August 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The said employees were told that they would be paid the salary for the month of September, but would number be required to work. They were also informed that retrenchment companypensation under s. 25F of the Act as well as pro rata dues on account of leave wages earned on 31st August, 1959 would be paid to them and their claims for Provident Fund dues would likewise be settled. In pursuance of these numberices, the eight employees were paid retrenchment companypensation due to them on the 31st August, 1959.

facts.text: Union protested retrenchment on 1st September 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On the Ist September, 1959, the Union representing the said employees, protested against the retrenchment in question.

facts.text: Court finds that after RBI approval on 15 July 1959, Vendee (Resp2) became owner and employer of the employees.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that on the 15th July, 1959, the approval of the Reserve Bank was obtained, and so, there can be numberdoubt whatever that as from the 15th July, 1959, the essential companydition precedent having been satisfied, the Vendee became the owner of the property.

facts.text: Retrenchment effected after transfer, by transferee (Vendee), invalid as non-compliance with s.25F and 25G, no proper reasons.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that Mr. Sen gupta is right in companytending that the Tribunal erred in law in holding that the impugned retrench- ment had been properly effected by the Vendor and that the only relief to which the retrenched employees were entitled was companypensation and numberice under s. 25FF of the Act.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, Tribunal award set aside, Resp2 directed to reinstate 8 workmen with continuity of service and back wages, adjust compensation paid.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the award made by the Tribunal is set aside and respondent No. 2 is directed to reinstate the 8 workmen without interruption of service and to pay them their back wages as indicated in this judgment Respondent No.

facts.text: 8 retrenched workmen: one Doctor, two Pharmacists, five clerical staff from Dispensary and admin.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst these 8 workmen, one was a Doctor engaged by the Vendor Co. in its Dispensary, two were Pharmacists in the said Dispensary and the remaining five were members of the clerical staff.

facts.text: Vendor's Manager Mr. Hammond continued in supervisory capacity under Vendee after possession handover.

anchor.surface_text: From the date of delivery of possession of the tea estate until the companypletion of the sale, the Manager of the Vendor companytinued to remain in the estate in a supervisory capacity under the management and companytrol of the Vendee.

facts.text: Vendee paid wages and leave pay to employees including 8 retrenched after possession.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the leave pay as well as the wages from day to day were paid by the Vendee to all the employees including the 8 retrenched workmen.

facts.text: No lay-off declared for Subong Tea Estate as Vendee opposed it, unlike other estates.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage, we may add that the vendee ultimately told Macneill Barry Ltd. that it was number agreeable to declare a lay off and accordingly, numberlay off was declared in respect of the tea estate in question, though it appears that lay off was declared by Macneill Barry Ltd. in respect of the other tea estates under their management.

facts.text: Sale deed consideration Rs. 3,75,000, deemed effective from 1st Jan 1959, purchaser to continue service or pay compensation except European/executive staff.

anchor.surface_text: The companysideration for the transfer recited in the saledeed is Rs. 3,75,000. By this sale-deed it was agreed that once the companyveyance was companypleted, the transfer was deemed to have taken effect from the 1st January, 1959, and the purchaser had companyenanted by this sale deed that he would be under obligation to every employee or labourer of the tea estate in question  except the European management and any other member of the Companys executive staff  either to companytinue his services on the same terms and companyditions of service as were applicable to him before the sale of the said tea estate, or to pay him companypensation Prescribed by law, subject to the other companyditions specified in the document.
Appeal by special leave from the award date July 5, 1961 of the Industrial Tribunal Assam Reference No. 39 59.

anchor.surface_text: Section 25F of the Act prescribes the companyditions precedent to a valid retrenchment of industrial employees. It provides that numberworkman employed in any industry who has been in companytinuous service for number less than one year under an employer shall be retrenched by that employer until one Months numberice has been served on him as prescribed by subsection  a  companypensation paid to him as provided for by sub-section  b , and numberice in the prescribed form is served on the appropriate Government as required by sub-section  c .

concepts.interpretation: Prescribes three conditions precedent (notice, compensation, government notice) to valid retrenchment; prima facie mandatory

concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure for retrenchment (last come, first go principle)

anchor.surface_text: Section 25G prescribes the procedure for effecting retrenchment. In substance, this provision requires that in the absence of any agreement between the employer and the workman, in effecting retrenchment in regard to any category of workmen the employer shall ordinarily retrench the workman who was the last person to be employed in that category, unless for reasons to be recorded the employer retrenches any other workman.

concepts.interpretation: Requires retrenchment ordinarily of last employed (last come first go), unless recorded reasons; non-compliance invalidates retrenchment

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: one year in that undertaking immediately before such transfer, shall be entitled to numberice and companypensation in accordance with the provisions o

concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure for retrenchment (last come, first go principle)

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 25H, a rule has been prescribed for the re-employment of retrenched workmen. This rule requires that after effecting retrenchment, if the employer proposes to take into his employment any persons, he shall give an opportunity to the retrenched workmen who offer themselves for re-employment and these retrenched workmen shall have preference over new applicants.

concepts.interpretation: Preference to retrenched workmen for re-employment

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the main question about the validity of the impugned retrenchment depends upon the applicability of s. 25FF of the Act to the facts of this case,

concepts.unlisted_description: Compensation to workmen in case of transfer of ownership or management

anchor.surface_text: Section 25FF deals with cases where the ownership or management of an undertaking is transferred. Such a transfer may be effected either by agreement or by operation of law. The section provides that in all cases which do number fall under the proviso to the section, on a transfer of ownership or of management of an industrial undertaking, every workman who has been in companytinuous service for number less than one year in that undertaking immediately before such transfer, shall be entitled to numberice and companypensation in accordance with the provisions of s. 25F, as if the workman had been retrenched.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to transfer of ownership/management entitling workmen to notice/compensation as if retrenched; does not apply here as retrenchment post-transfer by transferee

concepts.unlisted_description: Compensation to workmen in case of transfer of ownership or management

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the question of retrenchment in the light of the relevant provisions to which we have just referred, it is, however, necessary to bear in mind that the management can retrench its employees only for proper reasons. ... occasions may arise when the number of employees may exceed the reasonable and legitimate needs of the undertaking. In such a case, if any workmen become surplus, it would be open to the management to retrench them. Work- men may become surplus on the ground of rationalisation or on the ground of economy reasonably and bona fide adopted by the management, or of other industrial or trade reasons.

concepts.interpretation: Management has discretion to determine workforce needs but retrenchment valid only if bona fide for reasons like surplus due to rationalization, economy, or trade reasons; cannot be capricious

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, however, contended that at the relevant date when the 8 workmen were retrenched, respondent No. 2 was their employer, and so, respondent No. 1 had no authority to pass the orders of retrenchment.

arguments.court_reasoning: Vendee became owner post RBI approval on 15 July 1959 and managed estate as employer.

arguments.claim: Impugned retrenchment invalid as not justified under s. 25F and not carried out per s. 25G.

anchor.surface_text: It was further their case that the impugned retrenchment is invalid and illegal inasmuch as it is not justified under s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 (No. 14 of 1947) hereinafter called the Act, and has not been carried out according to the principles prescribed by s. 25G of the said Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Vendee effected retrenchment post-transfer without complying with s.25F/G; no recorded reasons or proper justification.

arguments.claim: Transfer of management took place on 17th February 1959 when possession delivered, retrenchment thereafter by Vendee must comply with s.25F/25G.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contend that in the present case, transfer of management took place on the 17th February, 1959 when the Vendor delivered over to the Vendee possession and management of the tea estate and the argument is that it is after the transfer of management thus took place that the retrenchment in question was effected.

arguments.court_reasoning: Transfer effective from 15 July 1959 post RBI approval; Vendee employer thereafter.

arguments.claim: Retrenchment validly effected by Vendor; employees entitled only to compensation under s.25FF.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has answered all these questions against the appellants, except in regard to two employees Mr. G. C. Bhattacharjee and Mr. P. K. Sarma Chowdhury in whose cases the Tribunal has recommended that respondent No. 1 should pay them gratuity ex gratia in such sums as respondent No. 1 may consider reasonable with due regard to compensation already paid to them.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: gupta is right in companytending that the Tribunal erred in law in holding that the impugned retrench- ment had been properly effected by the Vendor

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal erred; retrenchment by Vendee post-transfer, s.25FF inapplicable.

arguments.claim: On date of retrenchment, Vendor was employer; Vendee managed as Vendor's agent; no liability for Vendee.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the Vendee contended that on the date the impugned retrenchment took place, the Vendor was the employer and the Vendee was in management of the garden as the Vendors Agent. That is why no claim could be made against the Vendee by the retrenched employees,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the approval of the Reserve Bank was a companydition precedent, there can be numberescape from the companyclusion that after the approval was obtaine

arguments.court_reasoning: Post 15 July 1959 RBI approval, Vendee owner and employer; paid wages, controlled work.

arguments.claim: Delivery of possession on 17 Feb 1959 not transfer of management under s.25FF; conditions precedent (RBI approval, surplus staff retrenchment by Vendor) not satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri for the Vendee, on the other hand, strenuously argues that on the date of retrenchment, the Vendee was not in law concerned either with the ownership or with the management of the undertaking. According to him, the delivery of possession on which the appellants base their case, cannot be said to amount to the transfer of the management of the undertaking under s. 25FF.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the approval of the Reserve Bank was a companydition precedent, there can be numberescape from the companyclusion that after the approval was obtaine

arguments.court_reasoning: RBI approval on 15 July made Vendee owner; conduct showed employer status.

arguments.claim: s.25FF applies as retrenchment consequent on transfer terms (Vendee refused surplus staff).

anchor.surface_text: He contends that s. 25FF deals with the transfer of the undertaking or the transfer of its management. The first relates to the transfer of the title and the second to the transfer of management as distinct from title. His case is that the transfer which is evidenced by the conveyance executed between the parties on the 28th December, 1959 clearly shows that it was subject to two conditions it had to receive the sanction of the Reserve Bank and the Vendee had made it clear that the staff whom the Vendee regarded as surplus had to be retrenched by the Vendor before the Vendee could take over the undertaking as an owner.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , because they were virtually told that if they did number accept the companypensation, they would number receive their wages for the month of August.

arguments.court_reasoning: Retrenchment post-transfer by transferee (Vendee), not upon transfer; s.25FF inapplicable.

arguments.claim: Employees accepted retrenchment compensation, barred from challenging validity.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sastri sought to make a point against the appellants by suggesting that the employees had accepted retrenchment compensation and should not be permitted to question the validity of the retrenchment.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nsibly effected by Mr. Hammond is invalid be cause the Vendor Co. represented by Mr. Hammon had ceased to be the employer, then it would follow that t

arguments.court_reasoning: Technical pleas not entertained in industrial adjudication; employees protested next day under duress.

arguments.claim: From 15 July 1959 (RBI approval), Vendee became owner and employer.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that on the 15th July, 1959, the approval of the Reserve Bank was obtained, and so, there can be no doubt whatever that as from the 15th July, 1959, the essential condition precedent having been satisfied, the Vendee became the owner of the property.

arguments.claim: Vendee's conduct (paid wages, controlled/supervised work, decided lay-off, purchases) shows it was employer post-possession.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that the leave pay as well as the wages from day to day were paid by the Vendee to all the employees including the 8 retrenched workmen. The work done by the employees was controlled, directed and supervised by the Vendee.

arguments.claim: s.25FF inapplicable; retrenchment post-transfer by transferee (Vendee), not consequent upon transfer.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that Mr. Sen gupta is right in contending that the Tribunal erred in law in holding that the impugned retrenchment had been properly effected by the Vendor and that the only relief to which the retrenched employees were entitled was compensation and notice under s. 25FF of the Act.

arguments.claim: Retrenchment by Vendee non-compliant with s.25F (no govt notice) and s.25G (no last-come-first-go, no recorded reasons).

anchor.surface_text: It is conceded that if the retrenchment is held to be effected by the Vendee, it has not complied with s. 25F or s. 25G of the Act, and there can be little doubt that failure to comply with s. 25F would make the retrenchment invalid, and so would the failure to comply with s. 25G, because no reasons have been recorded by the Vendee for departing from the rule prescribed by s. 25G.

arguments.claim: No proper justification/reasons for retrenchment; must be bona fide (surplus, rationalisation, economy).

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the question of retrenchment in the light of the relevant provisions to which we have just referred, it is, however, necessary to bear in mind that the management can retrench its employees only for proper reasons. ... occasions may arise when the number of employees may exceed the reasonable and legitimate needs of the undertaking.

arguments.claim: No case made out for retrenchment at all; employees surplus not shown.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, we ought to add that no case has been made out for effecting any retrenchment at all, and as we have already emphasized, the employers right to retrench his employees can be validly exercised only where it is shown that any employee has become surplus in the undertaking.

arguments.claim: Retrenchment invalid; entitled to reinstatement with continuity and backwages, adjust compensation paid.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, we must hold that the retrenchment of the 8 workmen being invalid in law, cannot be said to have terminated the relationship of employer and employee between the Vendee, respondent No. 2 and the 8 workmen concerned. They are accordingly entitled to reinstatement with continuity of service they would also be entitled to recover their full wages

holdings.text: As from the 15th July, 1959, the Vendee became the owner of the property and the employer of the workmen.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that on the 15th July, 1959, the approval of the Reserve Bank was obtained, and so, there can be nodoubt whatever that as from the 15th July, 1959, the essential condition precedent having been satisfied, the Vendee became

holdings.reasoning_summary: RBI approval satisfied condition precedent to transfer agreement; Vendee in possession became owner; conduct (paying wages, controlling work, deciding lay-off) confirms employer status.

holdings.text: The impugned retrenchment cannot be taken to attract the operation of s. 25FF as it was effected after the transfer by the transferee who had become the employer.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned retrenchment cannot, therefore, be taken to attract the operation of s. 25FF at all. It is not retrenchment consequent upon transfer it is retrenchment effected after the transfer was made

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25FF applies to retrenchment consequent on transfer; here retrenchment post-transfer by new employer (Vendee), so full s.25F/G compliance required; Tribunal erred in applying s.25FF.

holdings.text: The Tribunal erred in law in holding that the impugned retrenchment had been properly effected by the Vendor and that the only relief was compensation under s. 25FF.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are satisfied that Mr. Sen gupta is right in contending that the Tribunal erred in law in holding that the impugned retrench- ment had been properly effected by the Vendor and that the only

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrenchment by Vendee post-transfer; s.25FF inapplicable; non-compliance with s.25F/G and lack of justification.

holdings.text: Failure to comply with s. 25F makes the retrenchment invalid.

anchor.surface_text: there can be little doubt that failure to comply with s. 25F would make the retrenchment invalid, and so would the failure to comply with s. 25G

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25F prescribes mandatory conditions precedent (notice, compensation, govt notice); no govt notice served by Vendee.

holdings.text: Failure to comply with s. 25G also makes the retrenchment invalid.

anchor.surface_text: and so would the failure to comply with s. 25G, because no reasons have been recorded by the Vendee for departing from the rule prescribed by s. 25G.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25G requires last-come-first-go unless recorded reasons; no such reasons recorded.

holdings.text: No case has been made out for effecting any retrenchment at all; retrenchment justified only if employee surplus due to bona fide reasons like rationalisation or economy.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, we ought to add that no case has been made out for effecting any retrenchment at all, and as we have already emphasized, the employers right to retrench his employees

holdings.reasoning_summary: Management discretion to determine needs but must show surplus for proper reasons (rationalisation, economy, trade); no evidence of surplus or bona fide reasons here.

holdings.text: The retrenched workmen are entitled to reinstatement with continuity of service and back wages, adjusting retrenchment compensation paid.
